summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons memorandum from the Warden of the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York to the Assistant Director of the Reentry Services Division, dated January 27, 2020. It is the institution's formal response to a 'psychological reconstruction' report dated December 27, 2019, concerning inmate Jeffrey Epstein. The document addresses multiple operational and procedural issues raised in the reconstruction, including video monitoring rounds, cellmate assignments, documentation accuracy, telephone calls, staff training, inmate accountability, and log book audits, in the wake of Epstein's death.

connections.description: The Warden is the head of the institution where Epstein was incarcerated and is formally responding to a report about his case.
The Chief Psychologist consults with the Associate Warden and other executive staff on housing decisions for inmates with psychological concerns.

keyFacts: The document is a response to a 'psychological reconstruction' of Jeffrey Epstein dated December 27, 2019, indicating a post-mortem review of procedures and incidents related to his incarceration.

It reveals a prior incident on July 23, 2019, involving Epstein where it was undetermined if he was assaulted or engaged in self-directed violence, and notes a 'local bias' among some staff in presuming it was self-harm.
A referral was made to the Office of Internal Affairs on August 29, 2019, regarding a policy violation for allowing Epstein an unmonitored phone call, which was pending as of this memo.
The institution implemented new procedures including weekly video reviews by a Captain and IDOs to ensure 30-minute rounds in the SHU, and daily bed book counts by Executive Staff.
An audit of log books revealed significant documentation failures, including missing pat search records and incomplete attorney logs, leading to new corrective measures.
